thread.title: Ford Engineer Develops Spare Tire Robot
thread.title_full: Ford Engineer Develops Spare Tire Robot

posts.author: Shane Laros
posts.title: Ford Engineer Develops Spare Tire Robot
posts.text:
Shane Laros posted on November 09, 2016 | | The Carr-E robot was developed as a personal mobility solution. (Image courtesy of Ford.) Every year, the Ford Motor Company encourages its employees to submit innovative ideas that could change the world. Some reach this lofty goal, while others are merely entertaining. 
One of the top ideas out of Germany for 2016 is the Carr-E, a spare-tire-sized personal mobility solution designed for the “last mile” - from your car to the office door, for example. 
Designed by Kilian Vas, a Ford systems engineer, the Carr-E can transport people or objects up to 120 kg, with a range of 22 kilometres (14 miles) and a top speed of 18 km/h (11 mph). It can be used to transport heavy items, as the device will follow an electronic transmitter the user can carry with them. 
This wasn’t the only mobility solution imagined this year, with other finalists emerging from the 633 entrants in the category. 
Other entrants included the TriCiti, a ridable device that can be adapted to carry items or folded down to ride on public transport or stored in a vehicle. The TriCiti has a range of 30 kilometres (19 miles) and a top speed of 20 km/h (12 mph). 
Another invention, the eChair, is a lightweight electric wheelchair able to load itself into a car, designed to offer greater independence to people with reduced mobility. 
“We really need to reinvent the wheel, to find new approaches to mobility,” said Vas. 
“When developing the Carr-E, I was inspired by Ford’s expansion into both an auto and a mobility company, but I’m also aware of how rapidly cities are growing and how getting around urban areas will become progressively more complicated. I really wanted to create a device that makes commuting easier and more fun.” Breakdown of the Carr-E. (Image courtesy of Ford.) Ford received numerous employee submissions in 2016, and is expecting to break the company record from 2015 of 6,000. Many of the submissions come from engineers throughout the company’s worldwide employee base. 
“Innovation and disruption is as much at the heart of how our engineers think now, as it was when Henry Ford first set about transforming the way we move,” said Walter Pijls, supervisor, Innovation Management for Mobility, Ford of Europe. 
“Personal assistant devices can help people to cover the final kilometres of their journey quickly and easily, and to transport heavy objects they might not be able to carry.” 
Mobility solutions are at the top of many people’s lists, but are not the only ideas being submitted. For more information visit Ford’s news page featuring of a few others , and visit the Ideas submission page . Recommended For You

thread.title: Why Ford is Building a New Technology Center in India
thread.title_full: Why Ford is Building a New Technology Center in India

posts.author: newsfeedback@fool.com (John Rosevear)
posts.title: Why Ford is Building a New Technology Center in India
posts.text:
Ford Motor Company (NYSE: F) said on Tuesday that it will invest $195 million in a new global technology and business center in Chennai, India, creating 3,000 jobs.
Ford said that its new center will "serve as a hub for product development, mobility solutions, and business services for India and the world." A new 28-acre "environmentally friendly campus" incorporating solar panels and water-recovery systems will house a total of 12,000 employees, 3,000 of whom will be new "highly skilled" workers, it said.

thread.title: Ford vows to work with Trump after criticism of Mexico investments
thread.title_full: Ford vows to work with Trump after criticism of Mexico investments

posts.author: David Shepardson
posts.title: Ford vows to work with Trump after criticism of Mexico investments
posts.text:
By David Shepardson WASHINGTON (Reuters) - No. 2 U.S. automaker Ford Motor Co <F.N>, which has endured scathing criticism from Donald Trump over its Mexican investments, on Wednesday congratulated him on his election victory and vowed to work with the president-elect.
"We agree with Mr. Trump that it is really important to unite the country, and we look forward to working together to support economic growth and jobs," Ford spokeswoman Christin Baker said.
Trump repeatedly said during the campaign that if elected he would not allow Ford to open a new plant in Mexico and would slap hefty tariffs taxes on Ford vehicles.
Ford shares dropped 2.6 percent to $11.18 on Wednesday.
Ford said in April 2015 it planned to invest $2.5 billion to build two new plants in Mexico, adding 3,800 jobs.
At his campaign kickoff speech in June 2015, Trump said he would call Ford Chief Executive Officer Mark Fields to explain the "bad news."
"Let me give you the bad news: Every car, every truck and every part manufactured in this plant that comes across the border, we’re going to charge you a 35 percent tax," Trump said then.
Earlier this year, Ford said it will invest $1.6 billion in Mexico for small-car production to start in 2018. In September, Ford confirmed that all of the company's small-car production will leave U.S. plants and head to lower-cost Mexico.
In his final speech of the campaign early on Election Day in western Michigan, Trump returned to the theme. "After we win, I'm going to be coming back to Michigan a lot. I'm going to be coming back every time we open a new factory or a new automobile plant ... We're not going to lose your jobs anymore," Trump said. "We are going to bring back the automobile industry to Michigan, bigger and better and stronger than ever before."
Last month, Ford Executive Chairman Bill Ford Jr. said he had met with Trump to talk about his extensive criticism of the automaker's investments in Mexico. Ford noted the automaker has hired 26,000 and invested $12 billion in the United States since 2011.
Bill Ford was in India on Wednesday after the company announced it will invest 13 billion rupees ($195 million) over the next five years in a technology and business center in Chennai. Ford said it will hire 3,000 people to staff the facility, which will be operational by early 2019.

(Reporting by David Shepardson; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama and Jeffrey Benkoe)

posts.title: Ford’s Garage coming Costco shopping center at Linebaugh and Sheldon
posts.text:
Ford’s Garage opened its first restaurant in 2012, in Fort Myers, and expanded to the Tampa Bay area in 2015, with its Brandon location.
Ford’s Garage is continuing its expansion with four new area restaurants slated to open in the next year.
“Our entire team has been working hard to prepare for this expansion,” said Marc Brown, managing partner. “We are excited to introduce our innovative and entertaining dining experience to new friends throughout Tampa Bay and its surrounding areas.”
In February 2017, Ford’s Garage Wesley Chapel will open across from the Tampa Premium Outlets. A Westchase location will open in March 2017, in the new Costco shopping center at the corner of Sheldon Road and Linebaugh Avenue. Ford’s Garage Countryside will open in April 2017, at 26210 U.S. 19 in Clearwater. And a fourth location is expected to open next summer in downtown St. Petersburg.
Ford’s Garage is known for its specialty burgers, home-style favorites, and one of the largest selections of American craft beer.
For more information, visit fordsgarageusa.com.

thread.title: Stronger Together in the Fight for Love
thread.title_full: Stronger Together in the Fight for Love

posts.author: Lisa Patrick
posts.title: Stronger Together in the Fight for Love
posts.text:
—
The first Presidential election I remember with Ford v. Carter. In my 8-year-old mind, this was a no-brainer. On the one hand, there was Gerald Ford, the President of the United States. I loved the guy, for reasons that aren’t clear to me 40 years later, and I thought he was doing a fine job.
On the other hand, there was Jimmy Carter, a peanut farmer from Georgia. Was this a joke? What on earth would make anyone think a peanut farmer should be President?
I remember being furious when Carter defeated Ford.
I see some parallels in this election. One the hand, there was Hillary Clinton, former FLOTUS, Senator, and Secretary of State, the most qualified yet most maligned, investigated and targeted for libel and slander candidate in the race, and arguably in history.
One the other hand, there was Donald Trump, a (predominantly failed) businessman, misogynist, xenophobe, and racist, the target of ongoing fraud investigations and the bringer of thousands of lawsuits. The least qualified candidate in the race, and arguably in history. He is everything our nation should stand against. What on earth would make anyone think this man should be President?
This time, I’m not furious. Last night as results rolled in, so did my anguish, and later, despondency.
Last night, evil won.
Hatred won.
Fear won.
Misogyny won.
Racism won.
Homophobia won.
Exclusion won.
Othering won.
And love lost.
But this is not the end. No, in fact, it is a new beginning. This battle may be over, but the war against oppression, the war for inclusion for everyone at the table of the American dream, that war wages on.
It is time, my friends, to roll up our sleeves and really get to work.
This work will be hard.
This work will be discouraging at times.
This work will be thankless at times.
But we cannot afford to assume someone else is going to do it. We cannot afford to think that love will magically prevail. We cannot afford to allow fear to deter us.
Last night, I was terrified and hopeless and, frankly, suicidal.
This morning, I am strapping on my armor, lacing up my shit kicker boots, and mustering all the forgiveness and love and faith I can manage.
This morning, I am ready to fight for all that is America. This morning, I am ready to fight for love.
Join me. Because we are still stronger together.
◊♦◊

Click the red “Now What?” button above to join our #Stop Racism group. Or, join The Good Men Project in a future Social Interest Group (“SIG”) on post-election reconstruction. Send a brief letter of interest and introduction to gmpsocialinterestgroups@gmail.com and we will send you the SIG information.
—
Photo credit: Pixabay 
 
 
The post Stronger Together in the Fight for Love appeared first on The Good Men Project .

posts.title: Ford F-150 Raptor: Pre-ordering for 2017 now open
posts.text:
Ford F-150 Raptor: Pre-ordering for 2017 now open The long-awaited Ford F-150 Rapter has finally become available for pre-order. Customers can also add some demands for customization. By Maisum Raza  20 PM EST Tag : ford , ford f-150 raptor , Ford Raptor , 2017 Sign Up for Newsletter This means you can contact your local Ford dealer for ordering information. The all-new Raptor is the truck that’s redefining off-road performance and attitude – (Photo : Ford (Official)) 
Ford is one of the world's oldest known car companies. The name ford brings up a nostalgic sense of pride whenever it is spoken about. Their cars are known to be some of the best in the world. Now, they have come back with yet another one. 
The Ford F-150 Raptor has been in the minds of truck fanatics for quite a bit now. Motor Trend really emphasizes on the end of the wait due to Ford's recent announcement of the pickup truck coming out in 2017. 
Ford is apparently already starting mass production of the car and this means that people can start ordering it now. Advertisement 
The concept of pre-ordering not only confirms that one will be the first batch of people to drive the beautiful piece of machinery, but it also insures a place for people who pre-order because if it comes out, the high demand may run the stocks dry. 
The basic Raptor has 450 horsepower and is being deemed as a supertruck for its amazing power. The pricing is adequate and floats just under 50 thousand US Dollars. 
The exterior of the truck, especially the front, has quite an intimidating look with very attractive headlights and a giant Ford logo out front that displays the beauty of Ford craftsmanship. 
However, Auto Blog mentions that there are various customization options. 
The basic truck model will be USD 50,000, but there are many customizations to choose from which change the exterior, interior, and the power of the truck. If all the best ones are applied, the price shoots up to a total of USD 70,000. That is an almost 150% price increase. 
That will not stop the public as Ford is claiming that 65% of the entire pre-building stock has been claimed already. 
Therefore, if anyone is interested in buying the car they should act fast.

thread.title: Patina 1930 Ford Model A Roadster Looks Like it Came Straight Out of the 1940s
thread.title_full: Patina 1930 Ford Model A Roadster Looks Like it Came Straight Out of the 1940s

posts.author: jroberts
posts.title: Patina 1930 Ford Model A Roadster Looks Like it Came Straight Out of the 1940s
posts.text:
Email 
Bountiful. 
The 1932 Ford has become the quintessential hot rod, thanks to its good looks and the fact that the model year coincided with Ford’s release of a V8 engine in addition to the reliable four-cylinder. While highly coveted by enthusiasts, the Deuce’s scarcity has made them expensive. Consider: Ford produced about 15,000 roadsters in 1932, while close to a half million Model A roadsters came off Ford’s assembly lines from 1928 to 1931. 
So original Model As, such as the car you see here, are easier to find and thereby represent a logical option for a hot rod with a traditional twist. Steve Green, the Canadian owner of this 1930 roadster, can attest to the fact. Having started a challenging ’32 Ford project, he ended up taking a break from it. “Nothing seemed to be going right with the five-window Deuce. So I shelved it for the time being. After a few months, I was getting the bug for building again and dragged out the 1930 roadster body I had in the shop. At first, I thought I would just weld in a few lower patch panels, get the shell squared up and back in shape. But everything was coming along so well that I decided I would just keep going and finish it up.” 
The Mission, British Columbia, resident knows a thing or two about building hot rods, having tackled several other projects in the past, including a 1936 Ford pickup well-known north of the border. It came to be after he discovered a Californian milestone, an equally cool ’35 truck built by Rudy Rodriguez featured in a handful of magazines. “I first saw the ‘Rudy Truck,’ as everyone calls it, in 2003,” he remembers. “It looked awesome, a totally different way of interpreting hot rods for me. Stripped right down, heavy chop, shortened box and frame, and a flathead Ford engine. I immediately knew this look was for me.” 
So Steve went to work to create his own “Rudy Truck,” armed with a magazine article and a few ideas. He bought an angle grinder and a MIG welder, learned how to use them, then cut the vintage Ford and stitched it all back together. It proved to be a steep learning curve, as he had little experience with such an ambitious construction, but it turned out great. 
At about the same time, Steve came to appreciate era-correct traditional hot rods, thanks in part to the renowned Burbank Choppers car club. The club has a deep understanding of our hobby’s early days, with the members’ rides staying true to the period, often to the last nut and bolt. In turn, these same vehicles contribute to the “hot rodding edifice” by inspiring gearheads such as Steve Green, who says, “I became familiar with the cars from the Choppers as they were making headlines and getting a lot of ink in magazines. Their style and taste for period-correct hot rods really resonated with me.” He also read as much as he could find on early hot rods and the pioneers who built them. “It was new to me, and I was fascinated by it all.” 
It was in 2011 that Steve set the frustrating coupe project aside and went to work on his A roadster, using an assortment of components gathered from all over the West Coast. He envisioned an era-correct hot rod with no compromise, though this type of build involves a certain level of historical knowledge, along with some serious commitment. 
“It took time to source all the period parts and collect the vintage speed equipment that has the right look and patina,” he explains. “The car had to look like it was built in the late ’30s or early ’40s. All the components came from swap meets here in British Columbia, as well as Washington State, Oregon, and even as far away as Pomona and Turlock in California. This hot rod really is just a sum of all its collected parts.” 
The first item on the agenda called for repairing the shell and creating a new floor in the back, due to the reshaped Model A frame, kicked up 5 inches in the rear. He additionally formed the drip rails in the trunk. Don’t be misled: What you see here is genuine patina and not a faux finish. Better yet, the various pieces of tin display matching colors and the same level of weathering, though they are all clearcoated for protection. The body remains pretty much stock, save for the chopped windshield frame and stanchion posts. Steve then used the press at Flat-Nasty Customs and patiently punched more than 50 louvers in the hood tops, followed by 186 in the trunk lid. The same shop helped him drop an original ’32 Ford axle, using a homemade jig, very much in the spirit of hot rodding’s early days. 
Other alterations to the frame include the adaptation of a ’32 K-member, complemented with lengthened ’34 wishbones. During his parts hunting, Steve had the luck of finding an old chromed drag link (which he connected to an early Ford F-1 steering box), as well as a handful of ’40 Ford parts (brakes front and aft, gauges and housing). The pedal assembly incidentally comes from a ’34 Ford. One easy way to personalize a hot rod consist of mixing and matching headlights and their supports, with fenderless rides often relying on individual mounts. Some folks prefer using a dropped headlight bar, though Steve elected to adapt a stock-height ’32 bar, but mounted pretty low, a look made popular a few years ago by the Rolling Bones team on the East Coast. While stock Model A lights are used up front, more unusual Electroline N5 marker lights equip the rear. These could be found on trucks, travel trailers, and boats occasionally. A 1930 British Columbia license plate with a cool vintage topper complete the tail end of the vehicle. 
Building a ’40s-correct roadster usually calls for the use of a four-banger or a flathead V8. Steve chose the latter, in the shape of a 239ci ’39 Mercury engine with an interesting story. “It was pulled out of an old hot rod back in the ’60s to make room for a small-block Chevy. It then sat around untouched for more than four decades.” The motor was simply freshened up with new stainless valves, new rings, and a custom-ground camshaft. A handful of other components give some grunt to the old V8, starting with owner-made headers. The list continues with an ancient Echlin coil, which relies on a light bulb as a resistor and a brass heat sink. Other noteworthy goodies include a pair of Stromberg 97s chromed many moons ago, a crab-style Ford distributor, and a 6-volt generator. 
Ponies then travel through a N.O.S. Hayes Racing clutch and a ’39 Ford gearbox, connected to a modified ’36 Ford driveshaft and Banjo with a 4.11 gear ratio. Among the inventive features of this project car, we should mention the custom electrical harness made from vintage cloth wiring salvaged from an old elevator. Finally, the driver side of the firewall displays a timeworn Mobilgas sticker that gave Steve some grief. “It was very delicate, and I tore it when trying to place it. So, I just made it work and clear-coated it. I was upset at first, but decided it looked cool anyway.” 
Steve found inspiration in the early pioneers of our scene when building his hot rod. “I would like to thank them, as well as the generosity of all my friends. I’ve learned a lot over the years and met a ton of great people.” The ’30 roadster has proven reliable and fun to drive, too, with a recent highlight including being part of the happy few who rode on Pismo Beach’s sand during The Race of Gentlemen. It allowed Steve to mingle with like-minded hot rodders, using a playground that our pioneers would have certainly approved, not far from the birthplace of our hobby. Does it get any better than this? The patchy paintjob, low slung Deuce headlight bar, and angled windshield, chopped 3-1/2 inches, contribute to the roadster’s sinister attitude. The ’30 body, from Washington State, proved in decent shape, simply requiring lower patch panels and fresh floor pans. Fake patina? No Sir, not on this puppy. What you see here is “enhanced Mother Nature rust brown with some original black,” as Steve describes it. With British Columbia’s climate being on the damp side, he keeps the metal from decaying by regularly using clearcoat and wax. The no-frills cockpit is home to a ’36 Ford steering wheel and a ’39 Ford shifter, which triggers a three-speed gearbox of the same origin. Steve additionally installed a unique shift knob, made by a good friend in high school back in the ’80s. We bet only a few readers will recognize the low-mounted seats as those out of a ’35 Chevy sedan. Or, what’s left of them when you remove the padding. Bolsters dressed with leather insure an acceptable level of comfort. The faded gauges and cluster left the Ford factory in a truck back in 1940. The V8 emblem to the right is an Art Deco-style badge found in Cad-LaSalle models—a gorgeous piece. Military surplus material often goes hand-in-hand with 1940s-style hot rods, as the equipment was cheap and plentiful after WWII. This gas mask pouch on the side of the cowl is a great touch: period correct and handy for storage, too. The trunk houses a 1960 VW Bus gas tank for no other reason than it was free and of the correct size. A pair of owner-made aluminum straps cushioned with military fabric keeps it in place. Under the floor hides a ’36 banjo rearend, along with its torque tube. Now featuring a compression ratio of 8:1, this 99T-style flathead V8 first motivated a Mercury back in 1939. The factory relieved block was bored 0.040 inches and is fitted with Grant piston rings, as well as a custom-ground 3/4-race Ford camshaft. Steve nickel plated the top of the vintage oil filter (known as a Kralinator Oil Conditioner) in, of all things, a Crock Pot. The process involved vinegar, some guitar strings, and a 6-volt battery! Topping an early Thickstun PM-7 high-rise intake manifold, the Stromberg 97 carbs keep debris at bay thanks to air cleaners of unknown origin found at a swap meet. Our resourceful owner added pot scrubbers underneath to serve as filters. “Made in Canada” aluminum heads? Yes, they came as standard equipment on many local Fords back in the day. “These higher compression heads fit the build perfectly, as they were sought-after in the ’40s by racers who could not afford the more expensive aftermarket heads,” Steve explains. Some hot rodders even painted them after removing the markings, making them the perfect “cheater heads.” Steve’s homemade headers flow into exhaust pipes made from ’36 Ford driveshafts. A few dozen louvers adorn both the hood and decklid. You can recognize the ’32 shell as a commercial unit, as it lacks the fancy chrome-plated die-casting that joins the radiator cap to the Ford script. The grille shell came from California, while Steve found the complete hood in British Columbia. Below the Model A headlights, check out the drilled genuine ’32 Ford axle, dropped 1-1/2 inches by Flat-Nasty Customs and Steve. More vintage components came from the Ford part bins, such as the ’35 Houdaille shocks, ’39 spindles, ’40 juice brakes (with drilled backing plate in front) and a ’48 F-1 steering box with a Model A flange. Louvers, Electroline taillights, and a Hollywood license plate lamp follow the 1940s theme of this very traditional hot rod. Originally fitted with skinny 19-inch rims, the A now runs 16-inch ’35 Ford wires. The bias-ply tires are Coker-supplied Firestone Deluxe Champs that measure 4.50-16 and 7.50-16 for a perfect rake. Minus its headlights and nicknamed Bad Apple, Steve’s roadster made the scene at The Race of Gentlemen in California. Here Steve and a buddy have just successfully negotiated the tricky downhill path to TROG’s pits. (Photo: Wes Allison)

thread.title: Ford prefers to keep low profile as he closes in on Virginia Tech's receiving records
thread.title_full: Ford prefers to keep low profile as he closes in on Virginia Tech's receiving records

posts.author: Norm Wood
posts.title: Ford prefers to keep low profile as he closes in on Virginia Tech's receiving records
posts.text:
Ford prefers to keep low profile as he closes in on Virginia Tech's receiving records Virginia Tech's Isaiah Ford on attention he's getting 
Isaiah Ford discusses spotlight on him as he pursues records 
Isaiah Ford discusses spotlight on him as he pursues records Norm Wood . "My focus is just trying to go 1-0, to be completely honest. If the record comes, then it comes. If not, then hey (it's OK)."
All of the commotion will probably die down quite a bit after the game against Georgia Tech (5-4, 2-4). He has 181 catches in his career, and he only needs four more catches to pass Jarrett Boykin (184 catches from 2007-2011) for Virginia Tech's career record. 
Ford, a 6-foot-2, 195-pound junior wide receiver from Jacksonville, Fla., already owns Virginia Tech's career receiving touchdowns mark. On Oct. 27, his 16-yard touchdown catch with 7:20 left in Virginia Tech's 39-36 win at Pittsburgh gave him 23 career touchdown receptions, moving him past former Virginia Tech receiver Antonio Freeman (22 touchdowns from 1991-94). 
By the end of the season, Ford should also own Virginia Tech's career receiving yards mark, as well. He has 2,583 yards, putting him just 302 yards away from surpassing Boykin (2,884). 
Against Georgia Tech, Ford will see an average pass defense that's giving up 236.9 yards per game (8th in the ACC) and which is tied for the third-fewest touchdown passes (10) surrendered in the ACC, but the Yellow Jackets have struggled the last two weeks. 
In last Saturday's 48-20 loss to North Carolina , Georgia Tech gave up 636 yards, including 353 passing. In a 38-35 win two weeks ago against Duke, Georgia Tech's defense was pounded for 559 yards, including 305 passing by freshman quarterback Daniel Jones. 
While Ford's productivity speaks to his easy rapport on the field with quarterbacks Jerod Evans and Brenden Motley and former Virginia Tech quarterback Michael Brewer over the course of Ford's career, there aren't any signs of an inflated ego to accompany what he's accomplished in just over 2 1/2 seasons. 
"He's done a great job of all of that," Virginia Tech coach Justin Fuente said regarding Ford's ability to deal with the spotlight. "He's a very mature young man, highly intelligent, truly interested in what's best for the team, but he also deserves recognition. He has been a good player here for several years. He's having a good season. He's done as good a job as anybody I've ever been around in terms of handling all the things that come with individual success." 
Last fall, Ford set Virginia Tech's single-season records for receptions (75), receiving yards (1,164) and receiving touchdowns (11). He also 
There's no shortage of well-meaning motivators to keep Ford grounded as he creeps closer to Virginia Tech's career marks. Expectations have understandably grown as his game has matured. 
Ford's mom, Jocelyn Grissett, drives from Jacksonville to all of Virginia Tech's games. The only one she missed this season was Virginia Tech's 34-3 win Oct. 8 at UNC in rainy, windy conditions caused by Hurricane Matthew. 
She was halfway up I-95 on her way to the Virginia Tech-UNC game before police officers told her and all accompanying traffic to turn around and go back because roads were too dangerous to drive on. 
With that kind of mother's devotion, she's come to anticipate big things from her talented son. She lets him know it in her somewhat tongue-in-cheek pregame texts. 
"She'll exaggerate a little bit with her good-luck texts and things and her expectations of what she wants me to do in the game," said Ford, who leads Virginia Tech with 50 catches (5th in the ACC) for 710 yards and six touchdowns. "I'm like, 'All right, mom. Come on, now. Let's be a little realistic.' 
"Every game is like, 'Yeah, I need like 250 yards and three touchdowns.' I'm like, 'OK. I'll see what I can do.'" 
Virginia Tech's 2016 season in photos. 
Purchase pictures by Daily Press photographers. 
After posting a career-high 11 catches for 117 yards and a touchdown in Virginia Tech's season-opening 36-13 win against Liberty, Hokies receivers coach Holmon Wiggins wasn't satisfied. He thought Ford's day could've been a lot better if he could've avoided a drop or two, blocked downfield a little better and finished plays a bit more. 
"That was an 'OK' day, in my opinion," Wiggins said three days after the Liberty game. "He knows that, because I expect more out of him. He should have had — well, I won't say — but it should've been a better day for him." 
Ford has seen his fair share of double coverage this season, but there are times when defenses have tried to corral him using man-to-man coverage. Of course, it's hard for teams to devote two defenders to Ford all game long when Evans also has productive receivers Cam Phillips (36 catches for 551 yards and two touchdowns) and Bucky Hodges (33 catches for 492 yards and 5 TDs) to target. 
Pittsburgh tried to load up to stop Virginia Tech's run, went with man coverage all game on Ford, Phillips and Hodges and paid dearly for its sins. Ford, Phillips and Hodges became the first trio of pass-catchers in team history to all have more than 100 receiving yards in a single game. 
When the season ends, Ford will have a big decision to make on whether he'll return to Virginia Tech for his senior year. 
ESPN draft analyst Mel Kiper considers Ford the fifth-best receiver available in the 2017 draft. He's projected to be a second-round pick if he enters the '17 draft, according to nfldraftscout.com, which also has him pegged as the eighth-best receiver heading into the draft. 
That's all stuff to address later this season or after the season. He keeps NFL aspirations, and any ideas related to impending records, on the back burner on game days. 
"I think in the heat of the game, I'm not really worried about, 'Catch this. This will be the record right here,' or anything like that," Ford said. "I'm just trying to make the play to help my team." 
Wood can be reached by phone at 757-247-4642

posts.title: Students Use Jazz To Encourage Unity | WFMYNEWS2.com
posts.text:
Students Use Jazz To Encourage Unity Togetherness, Why this Country is Great Hope Ford, WFMY 11:19 PM. EST November 09, 2016 A group of UNCG students stand on a downtown street corner, playing jazz to lift spirits and encourage unity. CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST 
GREENSBORO, NC – We wanted to know how people were feeling about America; what did they love about the country? 
Walking down the streets of downtown Greensboro, a few people stopped and gave a light sigh at the question. 
“I guess it’s just the ability to voice your opinion. The ability to like something, dislike something and be okay. I mean, we all have different opinions but at the end of the day we all have to live together,” said Jurita. 
Nathan, a passerby said, “We’re able to find a way to come together, put differences aside, move forward.” 
But when asking people how they felt, a saxophone and trumpets sounded in the air. Music bounced off the sides of buildings in the heart of the city. 
A group of UNCG students were standing on a corner, happily playing jazz music as people walked and drove by. Loading... The band- with no name, decided to take the streets one day after the election to play jazz to lift people’s spirits and show unity. WFMY The band- with no name, decided to take the streets one day after the election to play jazz to lift people’s spirits and show unity. WFMY The band- with no name, decided to take the streets one day after the election to play jazz to lift people’s spirits and show unity. WFMY The band- with no name, decided to take the streets one day after the election to play jazz to lift people’s spirits and show unity. WFMY The band- with no name, decided to take the streets one day after the election to play jazz to lift people’s spirits and show unity. WFMY The band- with no name, decided to take the streets one day after the election to play jazz to lift people’s spirits and show unity. WFMY The band- with no name, decided to take the streets one day after the election to play jazz to lift people’s spirits and show unity. WFMY Autoplay Pause Show Thumbnails Show Captions 
“What makes America great?” said Andrew Sanchez. “It’s a four letter word. Jazz.” 
The band- with no name, decided to take the streets one day after the election to play music to lift people’s spirits and show unity. 
“Jazz teaches us how to communicate with each other. It teaches democracy,” said Sanchez. 
After playing ‘When The Saints Go Marching In’, Sanchez added, “Everyone in the group knows their role. There’s a person that plays the melody, there’s a person that plays harmony. There’s a person that plays counter-melody, people that play rhythm. All these people are so very important in creating this beautiful art form and this one result.” 
Jazz music started in the late 19 th century as, in the simplest of terms, a mix of European classical music and African slave folks songs. It’s considered America’s oldest art form, as the genre is hard to define and changes constantly throughout the decades and among different musicians. 
Perhaps, it’s the best way to show a musical form of unity. 
“No matter who you were rooting for in this election, this is the music that reminds us why this country is so great,” Sanchez explained. “We can still come together and rejoice and have a beautiful time together.”

thread.title: Ford developing Evasive Steering Assist, Wrong Way Alert systems
thread.title_full: Ford developing Evasive Steering Assist, Wrong Way Alert systems

posts.author: Anton Andres
posts.title: Ford developing Evasive Steering Assist, Wrong Way Alert systems
posts.text:
Ford developing Evasive Steering Assist, Wrong Way Alert systems Text: Anton Andres / Photos: Ford   11:59 Ford lines up two active safety features for future models 
As vehicles continuously shift towards active safety, the Ford Motor Company is working on two features it plans to implement in its future models. The automaker is currently developing Evasive Steering Assist, as well as Wrong Way Alert system to mitigate, as well as to prevent collisions from happening in the first place. 
Ford describes Evasive Steering Assist as a last ditch option if a crash cannot be avoided by braking alone. Designed to operate at city and highway speeds, it uses radar and a camera to detect slower-moving and stationary vehicles ahead, and provides steering support to enable drivers to avoid a vehicle if a collision is imminent. The system doesn't steer for the driver. Instead, this feature only kicks in when the sensors detect obstacles that are fast approaching the car. Steering assistance is then given to the driver when he or she applies steering input. It works in conjunction with the stability control system to avoid further loss of control. 
The Wrong Way Alert system meanwhile aims to warn drivers if they are about to enter a one way street or the wrong side of the highway. Wrong Way Alert works with the use of a front mounted camera that constantly scans for road signs. If signs are unavailable, it then relies on the vehicle's navigation system to warn drivers of a no entry zone. It then alerts the driver with both audio and visual alerts to tell the driver to turn around. 
At the moment, both Evasive Steering Assist and Wrong Way Alert are being tested at Ford of Europe's grounds in Germany. Ford adds that they aim to introduce these new features within the next two years but did not say which cars will have it first. It is likely that the automaker's European lineup may be the first to get these systems as an option. Related Articles

thread.title: Ford Testing The Bronco Against The Jeep Wrangler In Australia's Outback
thread.title_full: Ford Testing The Bronco Against The Jeep Wrangler In Australia's Outback

posts.title: Ford Testing The Bronco Against The Jeep Wrangler In Australia's Outback
posts.text: Ford Testing The Bronco Against The Jeep Wrangler In Australia's Outback by Gabe Beita Kiser   More proof that Ford is dead serious about making this Bronco a winner. Watch out Jeep. With Chrysler struggling to keep itself relevant now that the 200 is being killed of and the 300 is next in line for the execution block , FCA is struggling to find ways to keep itself relevant while it decides what to do next. Luckily, some of its most popular models are there to keep things churning and as we’ve seen from renderings that have recently popped up on the Internet , the Jeep Wrangler's upgrades will be enough to keep the machine going. Motoring thinks differently, though. We recently got unofficial confirmation that Ford would be bringing the Bronco and Ranger back to the US from the UAW 900 plant chairman, Bill Johnson. Ford never followed up with its own confirmation, but thanks to the Australian automotive publication, we now have an added layer of security protecting the claims that both the mini truck and Jeep Wrangler competitor will make it to America. Motoring’s sources have confirmed that development for the Bronco is underway at Ford’s Victorian-based Asia-Pacific Product Development Center. The center is the home base for Ford’s T6 ladder platform that underpins the global Ranger and the upcoming Bronco. To migrate the platform, Ford will likely make alterations to allow for multiple body styles including two and four-door models. US buyers will probably not see the diesel options available to the global market, but we can be sure to expect a few V6 engines available including twin-turbo EcoBoost units. Unlike many of the softer SUVs Ford has put out to satisfy the crossover craze, the Bronco should retain a rough and rugged appearance as well as actual off-road capabilities. To make sure the Bronco doesn’t slip through the cracks and become a second-place option, Ford has reportedly purchased hardcore Rubicon versions of the two and four-door Wrangler in order to benchmark them against the Bronco. Don't Expect the return of the icon before 2020.

thread.title: Election: What President Donald Trump Means For Ford, U.S. Carmakers
thread.title_full: Election: What President Donald Trump Means For Ford, U.S. Carmakers

posts.author: Reuters
posts.title: Election: What President Donald Trump Means For Ford, U.S. Carmakers
posts.text:
The election of Donald Trump as U.S. president puts new pressure on automakers and other manufacturers that have become dependent on open trade with Mexico, and raises the risk they will face higher costs.
Automakers could also take a hit if instability in financial markets undercuts the confidence of consumers in the United States and other major markets at a time when growth in U.S. auto sales has stalled.
Investors sold off U.S. stocks and the dollar in reaction to Trump’s unexpected win. Shares in Japanese automakers, which also rely on Mexico as a production hub for the U.S. market, slid as well, underperforming the benchmark Nikkei index, which fell 5 percent.
In afternoon Tokyo trade, shares in Toyota Motor Corp were down 6.5 pct, Nissan Motor Co Ltd was down 6.0 pct, while Honda Motor Co fell 7.8 pct. All three companies declined to comment.
Trump’s promise to scrap the North American Free Trade Agreement and reject or renegotiate other trade opening deals resonated with voters in industrial states, even though many experts raised doubts that the 1994 NAFTA would be repealed.
Trump made an attack on the outsourcing of American auto jobs to Mexico a recurrent theme in his campaign, a message that rallied blue-collar workers while threatening to upend the business assumptions behind billions of dollars in planned investment by the auto industry.
In announcing his campaign in June 2015, Trump vowed to block Ford Motor Co from opening a new plant in Mexico and threatened to impose tariffs on cars it shipped back across the border.
But implementing Trump’s agenda would force U.S. consumers to pay higher prices for vehicles, said Charles Chesbrough, senior economist and executive director of strategy and research at the Original Equipment Suppliers Association, a Detroit-based trade group representing auto suppliers.
“His trade policies could add $5,000 or more to the price of a small car from Mexico,” he said.
U.S. manufacturers such Ford, General Motors Co, heavy equipment maker Caterpillar Inc and many of their suppliers have based billions of dollars of investment on the assumption of relatively open trade with Mexico, China and other countries.
Ford in April announced plans to invest $1.6 billion to expand production of small cars in Mexico, drawing fire from Trump. Trump also took aim at GM for its plans to invest $5 billion in Mexico.
In September, Ford said its small-car production would be leaving U.S. plants and heading to lower-cost Mexico, drawing another rebuke from Trump.
“We shouldn’t allow it to happen,” Trump said.
Ford Executive Chairman Bill Ford last month said he met with Trump to discuss criticism from the candidate, which Ford said he found “infuriating” and “frustrating.” Ford said his company employs more people at its U.S. plants than any other automaker. The company also said its decision to build new vehicles in Mexico would not cost U.S. jobs.
Between 1994 and 2013, U.S. auto factory jobs dropped by a third while jobs in Mexico rose almost five-fold over the same period as lower-wage production boomed.
Mexico now accounts for 20 percent of all vehicle production in North America and has attracted more than $24 billion in auto investment since 2010, according to the Ann Arbor-based Center for Automotive Research.
Based on current investment plans, Mexico’s auto production capacity will grow by another 50 percent over the next five years, the center, which draws funding from the auto industry, estimates.
“Dismantling NAFTA at this point would be pretty hard to do,” said Kristin Dziczek, director of industry, labor and economics at the center.
Recent pledges by GM and Ford to build new models at U.S. factories are likely to generate a limited new jobs, far short of the industry revival Trump promised on the stump.
“After we win, I’m going to be coming back to Michigan a lot. I’m going to be coming back every time we open a new factory or a new automobile plant, and we will do it and we will do lot of expansion,” Trump said in Michigan on Tuesday in his last speech of the campaign.

thread.title: 'Miles2Miami' ... Phoenix
thread.title_full: 'Miles2Miami' ... Phoenix

posts.author: John Singler
posts.title: 'Miles2Miami' ... Phoenix
posts.text:
7:53 PM The road to Ford Championship Weekend takes teams to Phoenix International Raceway, with just 312 "Miles2Miami" remaining in the 2016 Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup. John Singler 
The road to Ford Championship Weekend at Homestead-Miami Speedway takes teams to Phoenix International Raceway this week, now with just 312 "Miles2Miami" remaining in the 2016 Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup. 
Sunday’s Can-Am 500 will bring the Round of 8 to a close, trimming the field of title contenders to four. One driver from that quartet will be crowned NASCAR’s 68th Cup Series champion on Nov. 20 at Homestead-Miami Speedway. 
With victories the last two weeks, Jimmie Johnson and Carl Edwards know they'll be racing for a championship. That leaves six drivers chasing the two remaining spots. Kevin Harvick's an eight-time Phoenix winner but isn't resting on his laurels entering the next-to-last race of the season. 
"There are a lot of good drivers and lots of circumstances that could play out to have things go wrong," said Harvick, the No. 4 seed in this year's post-season Chase who is faced with what almost amounts to a a must-win situation on the one-mile desert oval. "You go there with a fresh start like you've never won before and just try to get the car dialed in." 
Harvick has won a race in each of the first two rounds of this year's Chase but has struck out so far in the semifinal round, posting finishes of 20th and sixth in his last two starts. 
"As we go to Phoenix, we have to look at the things we've done well there," Harvick said. "Pay attention to the lines and braking, steering and throttle. You try to mimic that immediately when you get on the racetrack." 
There are currently four drivers bunched within two points of each other who are very much in the mix for the final two spots in The Championship 4. Harvick is on the outside looking in, eighteen points below the cutoff line. 
He'll draw confidence from the fact he's won before at PIR, including earlier this season. 
In posting his eighth Sprint Cup win at PIR on March 13, Harvick survived a full-contact side-by-side duel with Edwards on the final lap to claim his first victory of the season in a photo finish. 
He led the field on the day’s final restart and pulled away before a fast-closing Edwards reeled him in and tapped the rear bumper of Harvick’s No. 4 Chevrolet entering Turn-4 on the final lap. Edwards pulled alongside and leaned hard on Harvick as they exited the corner. Edwards and Harvick bumped again as they took the checkered flag, with Harvick nosing ahead at the finish. 
The official margin of victory was a mere one one-hundredth of a second. Harvick dominated the second half of the race, leading all but 11 of the final 150 laps including the last 79. 
Seven of the eight drivers remaining in the semifinal round of the Chase have won a Cup Series race at Phoenix International Raceway: Harvick, Johnson, Edwards, Kurt and Kyle Busch, Denny Hamlin and Matt Kenseth. Joey Logano’s best finish there is third on two occasions, most recently in the November race last year. 
So far this fall, all eight post-season races have been won by drivers on the original Chase Grid. The best finish by a non-Chase competitor is Brian Scott’s runner-up effort at Talladega Superspeedway 18 days ago, when he finished second to Logano. 
Sprint Cup Series teams will open practice at Phoenix International Raceway on Friday at 1:30 p.m. (ET) and qualify later in the day. Motor Racing Network – "The Voice of NASCAR" – will have live coverage of Sunday’s Can-Am 500 starting at 1:30 p.m., with live streaming at MRN.com and on the MRN App. About Us

thread.title: Ford approaches Hokies' career receptions record | Virginia Tech Football
thread.title_full: Ford approaches Hokies' career receptions record | Virginia Tech Football | pilotonline.com

posts.author: pilotonline.com
posts.title: Ford approaches Hokies' career receptions record | Virginia Tech Football
posts.text:
BLACKSBURG Anytime he sets foot in a Blacksburg restaurant, Isaiah Ford knows what’s coming – the questions, the well-wishers, the compliments. It’s a steady stream.
Make no mistake, he’s flattered and honored to be considered one of the difference-makers when it comes to No. 18 Virginia Tech’s offense. Yet there’s also a part of him that’s ready for all the interest surrounding his pursuit of Tech’s career receiving records to go away.
“I go out to eat, and my waiter might say something like, ‘Hey, man. You going to break that record Saturday?’ or something like that, but once it’s be over, then it’ll be fine,” said Ford, who will help lead Virginia Tech (7-2, 5-1 Atlantic Coast Conference) on Saturday when it hosts Georgia Tech. “My focus is just trying to go 1-0, to be completely honest. If the record comes, then it comes.”
All the commotion will probably die down quite a bit after the game against Georgia Tech (5-4, 2-4). He has 181 catches and only needs four more to pass Jarrett Boykin (184 from 2007-2011) for Virginia Tech’s career record.
Ford, a 6-foot-2, 195-pound junior wide receiver from Jacksonville, Fla., already owns Virginia Tech’s career receiving touchdowns mark. On Oct. 27, his 16-yard touchdown catch with 7:20 left in Virginia Tech’s 39-36 win at Pittsburgh gave him 23 TD catches, moving him past Antonio Freeman (22 from 1991-94).
By the end of the season, Ford should also own Virginia Tech’s career receiving yards mark as well. He has 2,583, just 302 from surpassing Boykin (2,884).
Against Georgia Tech, Ford will see a pass defense that’s giving up 236.9 yards per game (eighth in the ACC) and which is tied for the third-fewest touchdown passes surrendered (10) in the ACC. But the Yellow Jackets have struggled the past two weeks.
In last Saturday’s 48-20 loss to North Carolina, Georgia Tech gave up 636 yards, including 353 passing. In a 38-35 win two weeks ago against Duke, Georgia Tech was pounded for 559 yards, including 305 passing by freshman quarterback Daniel Jones.
While Ford’s productivity speaks to his easy rapport on the field with quarterbacks Jerod Evans and Brenden Motley and former Virginia Tech quarterback Michael Brewer over the course of his career, there aren’t any signs of an inflated ego to accompany what he’s accomplished in just more than 2½ seasons.
“He’s done a great job with all of that,” Virginia Tech coach Justin Fuente said. “He’s a very mature young man, highly intelligent, truly interested in what’s best for the team, but he also deserves recognition. He has been a good player here for several years. He’s having a good season. He’s done as good a job as anybody I’ve ever been around in terms of handling all the things that come with individual success.”
There’s no shortage of well-meaning motivators to keep Ford grounded. Expectations have understandably grown as his game has matured.
Ford’s mom, Jocelyn Grissett, drives from Jacksonville to all of Virginia Tech’s games. The only one she missed this season was Virginia Tech’s 34-3 win Oct. 8 at UNC in rainy, windy conditions caused by Hurricane Matthew.
She was halfway up I-95 on her way to the game before police told her and all accompanying traffic to turn around because roads were too dangerous.
With that kind of mother’s devotion, she’s come to anticipate big things from her son. She lets him know it in her somewhat tongue-in-cheek pregame texts.
“She’ll exaggerate a little bit with her good-luck texts and things and her expectations of what she wants me to do in the game,” said Ford, who leads Virginia Tech with 50 catches (fifth in the ACC) for 710 yards and six touchdowns. “I’m like, ‘All right, mom. Come on, now. Let’s be a little realistic.’
“Every game is like, ‘Yeah, I need like 250 yards and three touchdowns.’ I’m like, ‘Okay. I’ll see what I can do.’ ”
After posting a career-high 11 catches for 117 yards and a touchdown in Virginia Tech’s season-opening 36-13 win against Liberty, receivers coach Holmon Wiggins wasn’t satisfied. He thought Ford’s day could’ve been a lot better if he could’ve avoided a drop or two, blocked downfield a little better and finished plays a bit more.
“That was an ‘OK’ day, in my opinion,” Wiggins said three days after the game. “He knows that because I expect more out of him. He should have had – well, I won’t say – but it should’ve been a better day for him.”
Ford has seen his share of double coverage this season. Of course, it’s difficult for teams to devote two defenders to Ford all game when Evans also has productive receivers Cam Phillips (36 catches for 551 yards and two touchdowns) and Bucky Hodges (33 catches for 492 yards and five touchdowns).
Pittsburgh tried to load up to stop Virginia Tech’s run, went with man coverage all game on Ford, Phillips and Hodges and paid dearly. They became the first trio of pass-catchers in team history to each have more than 100 receiving yards in a game.
When the season ends, Ford will have a big decision to make. ESPN draft analyst Mel Kiper considers Ford the fifth-best receiver available in the 2017 draft. He’s projected to be a second-round pick, according to nfldraftscout.com , which also has him pegged as the eighth-best receiver heading into the draft.
That’s all stuff to address later. He keeps NFL aspirations and any impending records out of his train of thought on game day.
“I think in the heat of the game, I’m not really worried about, ‘Catch this. This will be the record right here,’ or anything like that,” Ford said. “I’m just trying to make the play to help my team.”

thread.title: Ford, GM React to Trump Presidential Win

posts.title: Ford, GM React to Trump Presidential Win
posts.text:
Toggle the Motor Trend Mobile Search Search Motor Trend / Auto News / Ford, GM React to Trump Presidential Win Subscribe to the Free Newsletter Sign Up today for our FREE Newsletter and get the latest articles and news delivered right to your inbox. Subscribe Now Subscribe to the Free Newsletter Sign Up today for our FREE Newsletter and get the latest articles and news delivered right to your inbox. Subscribe Now Ford, GM React to Trump Presidential Win Trump's policies could have an impact on the automakers Trump's policies could have an impact on the automakers Share this article in: Free Price Quote From a Local Dealer View Special Offers No Obligation, Fast & Simple Free New Car Quote Change Car 3. Dealer Selection Receive your free dealer pricing information by completing your contact information! 
During his campaign for presidency, Donald Trump has threatened to renegotiate NAFTA and tighten up trade with Mexico, a market where both Ford and GM seek to expand in the coming years. But despite the potential negative consequences a Trump presidency may have on these automakers, they are taking the election results in stride, at least publicly. 
“GM congratulates both candidates and parties on their hard-fought campaigns.GM looks forward to working with President-elect Donald J. Trump and the new Congress on policies that support a strong and competitive U.S. manufacturing base,” the automaker said in a statement, adding that it “will continue to do its part to transform the future of mobility and contribute to America’s competitive strength.” 
Ford, which has been the most prized red circle on Trump’s target board, told Motor Trend , “We congratulate the President-elect and new governors, members of Congress and elected officials across all levels of the U.S. government. We agree with Mr. Trump that it is really important to unite the country – and we look forward to working together to support economic growth and jobs.” 
At the beginning of his campaign, Trump threatened to stop Ford from opening a new plant in Mexico , even saying he would impose tariffs on its cars shipped over here. Recently, Ford said it would move all of its small car production from the U.S. to Mexico over the next few years, substituting the cars with new products. Trump famously suggested Ford would “fire all of their employees in the United States,” to which Ford CEO Mark Fields retorted that no American jobs would be lost in the production shift. 
The president-elect has also expressed discontent at GM’s decision to spend $5 billion to expand its operations in Mexico. Just today, however, GM announced it would lay off 2,000 people and cut a shift at two of its factories due to slow sales. The affected plants include Lordstown, Ohio, which produces the Cruze , and Lansing, Mich., which builds Camaros and Cadillac sedans. 
If Trump’s protectionist policies see the light of day, small cars made in Mexico and shipped to the U.S. could become less appealing to U.S. consumers. Prices could go up $5,000 or more, warned Charles Chesbrough, senior economist at Original Equipment Suppliers Association, speaking with Reuters . 
While Ford and GM may have reason to worry, the mining and heavy equipment industries could benefit greatly. Investors are predicting that Caterpillar could benefit from Trump’s plans to curtail regulation in the coal industry. Shares for the company increased nearly 7 percent earlier today. 
Source: GM, Ford, Reuters

thread.title: Ford Ka Trail brings crossover traits to Sao Paulo Motor Show
thread.title_full: Ford Ka Trail brings crossover traits to Sao Paulo Motor Show

posts.title: Ford Ka Trail brings crossover traits to Sao Paulo Motor Show
posts.text:
By : Adrian Padeanu , Editor Ford’s smallest car on sale today will be available from early 2017 in a slightly more rugged configuration. 
Similar in philosophy with the VW cross up! , the new Ford Ka Trail is a pint-sized five-door hatchback with some crossover cues. It’s sitting slightly higher than the regular model as a result of a jacked-up suspension enabling a more generous ground clearance making it better at tackling bumpier roads. Some plastic body cladding around the wheel arches and a silver front skid plate have also been added to make the ruggedized hatch look more like a crossover. 
Rounding off the list of changes are the new 15-inch black alloy wheels complemented by a similar finish for the side mirror caps, and door handles, while the side profile has gained a “Trail” decal on the lower section of the doors. Images of the interior have not been provided, but chances a new seat upholstery and a different trim have been implemented to further differentiate the model from the regular Brazilian-spec Ka. 
Ford hasn’t released any technical specifications so far, although most likely underneath the hood resides the same 1.5-liter Sigma naturally-aspirated gasoline engine with 110 horsepower (82 kilowatts) and 107 pound-feet (146 Newton-meters) of torque. Power is channeled to the front wheels through a five-speed manual gearbox, while an optional all-wheel-drive system is out of the question since this is a cheap, no-frills car. 
Ford Brazil will have the Ka Trail on sale at the beginning of 2017, and although pricing isn’t out just yet, you can imagine the add-ons will command a premium over the regular Ka. The new Trail version will join the standard five-door hatchback model as well as the four-door Ka+ sedan available locally. Keep in mind a Ka+ model has been launched recently in Europe, but on the old continent it takes the shape of an Indian-built hatchback with five doors and serves as a replacement for the old Euro-spec, three-door Ka based on the Fiat 500. 
Source: Ford Brazil Be part of something big Ford Ka Trail at 2016 Sao Paulo Motor Show

thread.title: Ford To Invest $195 Million Into Indian Tech Center
thread.title_full: Ford To Invest $195 Million Into Indian Tech Center

posts.author: noreply@blogger.com (Brad Anderson)
posts.title: Ford To Invest $195 Million Into Indian Tech Center
posts.text: Ford To Invest $195 Million Into Indian Tech Center | By Share Ford has announced it will invest $195 million into a global technology and business center located in Chennai, India . The automaker confirmed that this center will serve as the base for mobility services and product development for India as well as a number of other unnamed markets . The investment will add 3,000 new employees in Chennai in the coming five years and when the center is constructed, house 12,000 employees, making it Ford's largest employment center behind its Michigan facilities. The Detroit News reports that the Chennai facility will include testing labs for future vehicles while also supporting employees focused on information technology, manufacturing, accounting and data. It will be the brand's third product development center in the Asia Pacific region. Discussing the center, Ford executive chairman Bill Ford said “India is not only a vibrant market for cars and new mobility ideas, it also is rich with talent, technical expertise and ingenuity. This new center will help us attract the best and brightest, and make Chennai a true hub of innovation for Ford around the world.” PHOTO GALLERY

thread.title: Wallabies recall Genia, Ford playing 100th test for Scotland
thread.title_full: Wallabies recall Genia, Ford playing 100th test for Scotland

posts.title: Wallabies recall Genia, Ford playing 100th test for Scotland
posts.text:
EDINBURGH, Scotland (AP) — Will Genia will be back at scrumhalf for Australia against Scotland on Saturday at Murrayfield, after missing the tour-opening win over Wales. Meanwhile, Scotland will feature a novel front row: Edinburgh loosehead prop Allan Dell will make his debut, tighthead Zander Fagerson earns his first start, and hooker Ross Ford becomes the third Scot to reach 100 tests.
Genia wasn't released by French club Stade Francais because the Wales match was outside the test window. But available again, he was chosen immediately by Wallabies coach Michael Cheika on Thursday.
In replacing Nick Phipps, who was in the reserves, Genia was the only change to the starting XV which thumped Wales 32-8 in Cardiff last weekend.
"Genia ... he's been one of our best all season," Cheika said. "Nick will finish the game."
Utility forward Dean Mumm was in the reserves after a one-match suspension, along with lock Will Skelton, who hasn't played since August. The forwards-backs split in the reserves was 5-2, perhaps in mind of the weather forecast, which is for rain. Australia's tight five was also criticized, even after dominating Wales, and Cheika expected them to be targeted.
"We're going to have to learn how to win in different ways on this trip," he said. "It can't always be like the way it was last week."
Cheika kept faith with No. 8 Lopeti Timani, who excelled even after David Pocock left the Wales game early because of a concussion. Pocock was passed fit.
Ford, who made his Scotland debut against Australia in 2004, follows only Chris Paterson (109) and Sean Lamont (105) to a century of caps.
His experience will be vital in the front row, between South African-born clubmate Dell, and 20-year-old Fagerson.
"He has plenty left to give in a Scotland jersey," Scotland coach Vern Cotter said of Ford.
Regular props Alasdair Dickinson (hamstring) and WP Nel (neck) were injured. Gordon Reid and Moray Low were the backups.
Backs Finn Russell and Alex Dunbar return after injuries ruled them out of the Japan tour in June, when Scotland won both tests. Dunbar forms a new center partnership with Stormers center Huw Jones, who made his debut in Japan.
___
Lineups:
Scotland: Stuart Hogg, Sean Maitland, Huw Jones, Alex Dunbar, Tim Visser, Finn Russell, Greig Laidlaw (captain), Ryan Wilson, Hamish Watson, John Barclay, Jonny Gray, Richie Gray, Zander Ferguson, Ross Ford, Allan Dell. Reserves: Fraser Brown, Gordon Reid, Moray Low, Grant Gilchrist, John Hardie, Ali Price, Pete Horne, Rory Hughes.
Australia: Israel Folau, Dane Haylett-Petty, Tevita Kuridrani, Reece Hodge, Henry Speight, Bernard Foley, Will Genia; Lopeti Timani, Michael Hooper, David Pocock, Adam Coleman, Rory Arnold, Sekope Kepu, Stephen Moore (captain), Scott Sio. Reserves: Tolu Latu, Tom Robertson, Allan Alaalatoa, Rob Simmons, Will Skelton, Dean Mumm, Nick Phipps, Quade Cooper.

thread.title: Ford planning a four-car effort at 2017 Rolex 24
thread.title_full: Ford planning a four-car effort at 2017 Rolex 24

posts.title: Ford planning a four-car effort at 2017 Rolex 24
posts.text:
Ford planning a four-car effort at 2017 Rolex 24 There could be four Ford GTs racing around Daytona in January. 
Ford GT team photo ahead of the 2016 running of the 24 Hours of Le Mans. (Photo: Jakob Ebrey/LAT Photographic) By John Dagys Nov 9, 2016 at 4:03p ET 0Shares 
Following its 24 Hours of Le Mans triumph last June, Ford is pulling out all the stops in quest of class victory in another twice-around-the-clock endurance classic, with the American manufacturer planning a four-car Ford GT effort for the Rolex 24 at Daytona. 
Sportscar365 has learned that Ford Chip Ganassi Racing is preparing to enter all four of its cars in the IMSA WeatherTech SportsCar Championship season opener on Jan. 28-29, in what would mark the team’s biggest single-class, single-race effort in North America. 
While a formal commitment or announcement has not yet been made, it’s understood preparations are underway, with the team’s FIA World Endurance Championship cars expected to be shipped to the U.S. following next weekend’s season finale in Bahrain for pre-race preparations. 
Drivers from the team’s WEC program, plus some potential Ganassi NASCAR and IndyCar drivers, are expected to complete the four-car lineup in the GT Le Mans class. 
When reached by Sportscar365, Ford Performance global director Dave Pericak didn’t confirm or deny the presence of a likely increased effort for Daytona. 
“Our Ford team is completely focused on the remaining WEC schedule and are extremely proud and happy with our Ford GT performance worldwide,” Pericak told Sportscar365. 
The Multimatic-built Ford GT made its competition debut in this year’s Rolex 24 and since went on to claim three WeatherTech Championship class victories, all with the No. 67 car of Richard Westbrook and Ryan Briscoe, as well as the 24 Hours of Le Mans with Joey Hand, Dirk Mueller and Sebastien Bourdais. 
Its UK-based, Multimatic-run branch has also tasted success in the car’s first year, with class wins in the two recent WEC rounds at Fuji and Shanghai, both with Andy Priaulx and Harry Tincknell. 
Ford’s expected increased effort for Daytona will come as significant boost to the GTLM class, which will again see factory or works-backed efforts from BMW, Porsche, Ferrari and defending champions Corvette Racing. 0

thread.title: Tiniest Dancer: The Ford EcoSport Is Coming to America
thread.title_full: Tiniest Dancer: The Ford EcoSport Is Coming to America

posts.author: Steph Willems
posts.title: Tiniest Dancer: The Ford EcoSport Is Coming to America
posts.text:
Tweet 
Ford’s smallest utility vehicle is bound for North America, giving hope to Blue Oval fans who find an Escape too unwieldy. 
The EcoSport, offered in overseas markets since 2004, will soon be pressed into service to round out the bottom of the Ford’s domestic utility lineup. 
According to Automotive News , Ford can blame the leak on DJ Khaled, who teased his involvement in the reveal on Snapchat last night. 
“Monday I’m introducing the Ford EcoSport,” the rap artist said in a short video. “It’s going to be a world premiere with the new Ford EcoSport.” 
The unveiling comes on the eve of the Los Angeles International Auto Show. While Ford has confirmed the decision to bring the model stateside, it won’t say when it will go on sale. 
Sharing its B3 platform with the Ford Fiesta, the EcoSport offers differing powerplants depending on the market, though a 1.0-liter EcoBoost three-cylinder comes standard in most countries. Select countries see non-turbocharged gasoline and diesel 1.5-liter four-cylinders, as well as a 1.6-liter and 2.0-liter four. Ford hasn’t mentioned what powertrains North American customers can expect. 
The automaker clearly doesn’t like the idea of being left out of the small but fast-growing subcompact crossover segment, dominated by the likes of the Chevrolet Trax and Mazda CX-3. While only 3 percent of U.S. volume, the segment has seen sales rise by 30 percent this year. 
[Image: Ford of Europe]

thread.title: Rugby-Ford set to become Scotland centurion against Australia
thread.title_full: Rugby-Ford set to become Scotland centurion against Australia

posts.title: Rugby-Ford set to become Scotland centurion against Australia
posts.text:
11pm GMT Ford set to become Scotland centurion against Australia Scotland's Ross Ford during training. Rugby Union - Scotland Training - Surrey Sports Park - 14/10/15.   Andrew Boyers Livepic 
LONDON Hooker Ross Ford will become only the third player to reach 100 caps for Scotland as he spearheads a new-look front row against Australia on Saturday. 
Ford, who made his debut against Australia 12 years ago, will join Chris Paterson (109) and Sean Lamont (105) as Scotland's only cap centurions when Vern Cotter's side open their autumn campaign at Murrayfield. 
His experience could prove vital as he will line up alongside debutant Allan Dell and Zander Fagerson, who makes his first international start. 
“To play 100 test matches for your country is an incredible achievement, with his lasting dedication keeping him among the best hookers in the world for a decade," Cotter said in a statement. 
“He is a consummate professional and, at 32, he has plenty left to give in a Scotland jersey.” 
Flanker Hamish Watson and centre Huw Jones will also make their first test starts as Scotland face Australia for the first time since their heartbreaking 35-34 defeat in the World Cup quarter-final last year. 
That match holds painful memories for Cotter's side, who had been on the verge of a stunning upset, before Australia snatched victory with a last-gasp penalty by Bernard Foley that many observers felt should not have been awarded. 
Team: 15-Stuart Hogg, 14-Sean Maitland, 13-Huw Jones, 12-Alex Dunbar, 11-Tim Visser, 10-Finn Russell, 9-Greig Laidlaw, 1-Allan Dell, 2-Ross Ford, 3-Zander Fagerson, 4-Richie Gray, 5-Jonny Gray, 6-John Barclay, 7-Hamish Watson, 8-Ryan Wilson 
Replacements: 16-Fraser Brown, 17-Gordon Reid, 18-Moray Low, 19-Grant Gilchrist, 20-John Hardie, 21-Ali Price, 22-Pete Horne, 23-Rory Hughes 
(Reporting by Toby Davis, editing by Pritha Sarkar) Next In Sports News

After purchased his GT new, Krachun added a Harwood cowl hood, a GT500 spoiler, Raxiom halo foglights, an RTR decklid, Coyote badges, Eleanor scoops, and chrome GT500 wheels from AmericanMuscle.com. thread.title: Why Ford's Smallest SUV, the 2017 EcoSport, Is Coming to the U.S.
thread.title_full: Why Ford's Smallest SUV, the 2017 EcoSport, Is Coming to the U.S.

posts.author: newsfeedback@fool.com (John Rosevear)
posts.title: Why Ford's Smallest SUV, the 2017 EcoSport, Is Coming to the U.S.
posts.text:
Why Ford's Smallest SUV, the 2017 EcoSport, Is Coming to the U.S. newsfeedback@fool.com (John Rosevear) 1 hr ago A Ford EcoSport Titanium, as sold in Europe. Ford will announce next week that the EcoSport, a subcompact SUV, is coming to the U.S. Image source: Ford Motor Company. 
Ford Motor Company (NYSE: F) is about to bring its smallest SUV to the United States. As first reported by Automotive News , the Blue Oval has confirmed that a U.S.-bound version of the 2017 Ford EcoSport will be unveiled in Los Angeles on Monday. What is the Ford EcoSport? 
The EcoSport is a small crossover SUV built on Ford's global "B" architecture. That architecture is shared with the Fiesta, which should give you an idea of the EcoSport's size. (It's a little bigger than a Fiesta.) While it will be new to the U.S., the EcoSport isn't an all-new product. 
The current EcoSport is part of Ford's global product portfolio and has been sold in many other parts of the world since its launch late in 2012 as a 2013 model. It was originally developed as a simple and inexpensive SUV for emerging markets. Ford sells a lot of them: The EcoSport is currently built in China, Brazil, Russia, India, Vietnam, and Thailand. 
A more upscale version of the EcoSport was subsequently developed for Europe and launched last year to compete with popular premium small SUVs like General Motors ' (NYSE: GM) Opel Mokka. That's probably the version that will serve as the basis of the U.S. model, and it will probably have the Mokka's U.S. sibling -- the hot-selling Buick Encore -- in its sights. 
In Europe, the EcoSport is available with three different engines, including a diesel. It's likely that the U.S. model will be offered with some or all of these gasoline engines: a 1.6-liter four-cylinder making 120 horsepower, a 1.0-liter three-cylinder EcoBoost turbo making 123 horsepower, or a 2.0-liter four-cylinder making 160 horsepower. 
The European EcoSport is available in upscale trims, including "Titanium" and "Titanium Sport" models. Expect the U.S. model's trim lines to follow the pattern of the Fiesta and Focus, with two or three versions -- including an upscale model -- available. The U.S.-market EcoSport's interior will probably look a lot like the one in this European model. Image source: Ford Motor Company. 
The U.S.-market EcoSport probably won't be built in the U.S., as most of Ford's U.S. factories are already running near full capacity. It might be built in Mexico, possibly alongside current U.S.-bound Fiestas at Ford's Cuautitlan Stamping and Assembly plant in Cuautitlan Izcalli, Mexico. Also possible: Ford may choose to import U.S.-market EcoSports from its vast manufacturing facility in Thailand. Why is the EcoSport coming to the U.S.? 
Let's put it this way: Here are the key competitors in the subcompact SUV segment in the U.S. Note that most have had big sales increases this year. Data sources: The automakers. Year-to-date sales are through Oct. 31, 2016. 
So to answer the question: Ford wants a piece of that fast-growing action. Since the EcoSport already exists, entering the U.S. small-SUV fray is a (relatively) inexpensive proposition for the Blue Oval -- and the profit potential is quite high. What will the new Ford EcoSport cost? 
We don't know yet. Ford may tell us on Monday, or it may wait until closer to the EcoSport's launch. My educated guess is that the U.S. EcoSport's starting price will be right around $20,000, with a "Titanium" version starting around $26,000. You'll probably be able to get a well-equipped-but-not-lavish EcoSport for around $24,000, maybe a little less. When will the EcoSport go on sale in the U.S.? 
Again, we don't know yet, though Ford will almost certainly give us an idea on Monday. The timing of the EcoSport's U.S. launch probably depends on where Ford plans to build it. 
If the answer is Mexico, it might take a while: Ford is in the process of a massive expansion of its Mexican manufacturing facilities, with an all-new assembly plant under construction in San Luis Potosi and a major expansion of the Cuautitlan plant underway now. 
If the answer is Thailand, the EcoSport could arrive at U.S. dealers much sooner. 
10 stocks we like better than Ford 
When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip, it can pay to listen. After all, the newsletter they have run for over a decade, Motley Fool Stock Advisor , has tripled the market.* 
David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the ten best stocks for investors to buy right now... and Ford wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better buys.

posts.title: Redesigned 2017 Ford EcoSport coming to America; subcompact crossover to debut before LA Auto Show
posts.text:
Pinterest Email 
Ford Motor Co. on Monday will unveil a new EcoSport subcompact crossover for the North American market in advance of the 2016 Los Angeles Auto Show . 
Rap artist DJ Khaled posted on Snapchat late Wednesday night that he would be in L.A. to help unveil the vehicle next week. “Monday I’m introducing the Ford EcoSport,” Khaled said in the short video. “It’s going to be a world premiere with the new Ford EcoSport.” 
A spokesman for the Dearborn automaker confirmed the release late Wednesday, but did not immediately say when the vehicle would go on sale. 
Ford has sold the EcoSport for years in Europe, and former CEO Alan Mulally said in the past that the crossover would eventually be sold in the U.S. 
Ford earlier this year said it planned to introduce four all-new utility vehicles to its Ford and Lincoln brands. Ford’s lineup includes the Edge, Escape, Explorer and Expedition. Lincoln has the MKC, MKX, MKT and Navigator. 
Ford confirms it will bring EcoSport subcompact crossover to N.A. originally appeared on Automotive News . 
By Michael Martinez, Automotive News READ THIS NEXT

thread.title: Ford to unveil small EcoSport SUV next week in LA
thread.title_full: Ford to unveil small EcoSport SUV next week in LA

posts.author: detroitnews.com
posts.title: Ford to unveil small EcoSport SUV next week in LA
posts.text:
Ford will unveil a “new” EcoSport small SUV on Monday in Los Angeles for the U.S. The automaker currently sells the vehicle in global markets, including the European version pictured here. (Photo: Ford Motor Co.) 
Ford Motor Co. will unveil its all-new Ford EcoSport next week ahead of the Los Angeles Auto Show.
The reveal was announced late Wednesday by DJ Khaled via Snapchat , saying he would be unveiling the subcompact SUV on Monday.
“It’s going to be a world premier with this new EcoSport,” he said in the ad, which followed videos of him driving in a Rolls-Royce convertible.
Ford confirmed the debut Thursday morning, however did not provide any details on the vehicle.
The EcoSport is expected to be the smallest utility vehicle from the Dearborn-based automaker for the U.S. It is currently produced in Brazil, India, Thailand and Russia.
Ford introduced the first generation of the EcoSport in select markets in 2003. A second generation of the small utility vehicle launched in Brazil and other global markets in 2012.
Small crossovers/SUVs are expected to be a major part of the LA Auto Show, which officials say will feature more than 50 vehicle debuts for the show’s press days Nov. 14-17.
Toyota at the LA show also will reveal a compact crossover, the 2018 C-HR. Toyota says the new vehicle will bow Nov. 17.
Mazda plans to reveal its redesigned 2017 CX-5 compact SUV at the show on Wednesday.
The Jeep Compass compact SUV will make its North American debut for Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV alongside an all-new SUV from Italian brand Alfa Romeo. 
According to Fordpresents.com, which DJ Khaled referred to in his Snapchat video, the unveiling is part of a three-day event in Los Angeles called “Go Small. Live Big.” The event will feature performances by several special guests as well as tastings from restaurants in Los Angeles.
